Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the late 13th century, Osman I 
established a small beylik, or principality, in what is now Turkey. In just a few generations, this beylik
outmaneuvered more powerful neighbors to become the vast Ottoman empire. What enabled its rapid rise? In Osman’s time, the Anatolian peninsula
was a patchwork of Turkic principalities sandwiched between a crumbling
Byzantine Empire and weakened Sultanate
of the Seljuk of Rum. Osman quickly expanded this territory through a mixture of strategic
political alliances and military conflicts 
with these neighbors, attracting mercenaries first
with the promise of booty, then later through his reputation 
for winning. Osman was the first in a line 
of Ottoman rulers distinguished by their political shrewdness. Often prioritizing political and military
utility over ethnic or religious affinity, they expanded their influence by fighting
along certain sides when needed, and fighting against them 
when the time was right. After Osman’s death his son Orhan established a sophisticated military
organization and tax collection system geared towards funding 
quick territorial expansion. The Ottomans’ first major expansion
was in the Balkans, in southeast Europe. The military employed a mixture
of Turkic warriors and Byzantine and other Balkan Christian converts. They captured thousands 
of young Christian boys from villages from across the Balkans, converted them to Islam, and trained
them to become the backbone of a fierce military elite force
known as the Janissaries. The captured enslaved boys could rise
to the high position of a vizier in the Ottoman government. Rulers of conquered areas were
also allowed, even encouraged, to convert to Islam and take positions
in the Ottoman government. Meanwhile, non-Muslims 
who belonged to Abrahamic religions were allowed religious freedom 
in exchange for a tax known as Jizye, among other strict conditions— for example, they were not allowed
to join the army. By the end of the 14th century, 
the Ottomans had conquered or subordinated most of the Anatolian beyliks 
as well as the Balkans. But in the first half of the 15th century, as Sultan Beyazit I focused
on Western expansion, the Central Asian ruler Timur attacked
from the east. He captured Beyazit and carted
him off in an iron cage, sparking a ten year struggle 
for succession that almost destroyed the Ottoman empire. Sultan Murad II turned this trend around, but fell short of one 
of his loftiest goals: capturing the Byzantine capital,
Constantinople. His son, Sultan Mehmed II, 
or Mehmed the Conqueror, vowed to succeed where his father
had failed. In preparation for the attack 
on Constantinople, he hired a Hungarian engineer 
to forge the largest cannon in the world, used Serbian miners to dig tunnels
under the walls of the city, and ordered his fleet of ships
to be carried overland, attacking the city 
from an unexpected direction. He laid siege to the city 
and in the spring of 1453, Constantinople fell to the Ottomans. It would become the Ottoman capital, 
known by its common Greek name, Istanbul, meaning “to the city.” By the time Mehmed II
conquered Constantinople, the city was a shadow of its former glory. Under Ottoman rule, 
it flourished once again. On an average day in Istanbul, you could
hear people speaking Greek, Turkish, Armenian, Persian, Arabic, Bulgarian,
Albanian, and Serbian. Architects like the famous Sinan
filled the city with splendid mosques and other buildings commissioned
by the sultans. Through Istanbul, the Otttomans brought
commodities like coffee to Europe. They entered a golden age 
of economic growth, territorial acquisition, 
art and architecture. They brought together craftspeople 
from across Europe, Africa, the Middle East and Central Asia to create
a unique blend of cultural innovation. Iznik ceramics, for example, were made using techniques
from China’s Ming dynasty, reimagined with Ottoman motifs. The Ottomans would continue to expand, cementing their political influence
and lucrative trade routes. The empire lasted for more than 600 years 
and, at its peak, stretched from Hungary
to the Persian Gulf, from the Horn of Africa
to the Crimean Peninsula.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Under Ottoman Islamic rule non-Mulsims identifying as members of ------ religious communities were allowed religious freedoms:
Options: A. Orthodox Christian, B. Jewish, C. Catholic Christians, D. Jewish and Christian, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the founder of the Ottoman Empire? Options: A. Sultan Beyazit I, B. Sultan Murad II, C. Osman I, D. Timur Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the name of the tax that non-Muslims belonging to Abrahamic religions had to pay in exchange for religious freedom? Options: A. Jizya, B. Jizye, C. Zakat, D. Ushr Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the name of the elite military force that was formed by the Ottomans using captured Christian boys? Options: A. Janissaries, B. Mamluks, C. Spahis, D. Akıncılar Correct Option: A
Question 4: Who was the Central Asia ruler who attacked the Ottoman Empire from the east and captured Sultan Beyazit I? Options: A. Timur, B. Tamerlane, C. Genghis Khan, D. Babur Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the name of the city that the Ottomans conquered in 1453, which became their capital? Options: A. Constantinople, B. Istanbul, C. Edirne, D. Bursa Correct Option: A
Question 6: Who was the Hungarian engineer who forged the largest cannon in the world for Sultan Mehmed II? Options: A. Orban, B. Urbain, C. Urban, D. Ural Correct Option: A
Question 7: What architectural style was popular during the Ottoman Empire, characterized by the use of domes and minarets? Options: A. Islamic architecture, B. Ottoman architecture, C. Byzantine architecture, D. Seljuk architecture Correct Option: B
Question 8: How did the Ottomans expand their influence in the Balkans? Options: A. By capturing thousands of young Christian boys from villages across the Balkans, converting them to Islam, and training them to become soldiers, B. By establishing trade routes and economic ties, C. By forming alliances with local rulers and converting local Christians to Islam, D. By relying on their naval power Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the significance of the capture of Constantinople by the Ottomans in 1453? Options: A. It marked the end of the Ottoman Empire's golden age, B. It marked the beginning of the Ottoman Empire's expansion into Europe, C. It marked the end of the Byzantine Empire, D. It led to the decline of the Byzantine Empire Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the impact of the Ottoman Empire's expansion on the city of Istanbul? Options: A. It led to the destruction of the city's infrastructure, B. It led to the decline of the city's population and economy, C. It brought together people from across Europe, Africa, the Middle East, and Central Asia, creating a unique blend of cultural innovation, D. It resulted in the spread of Islam throughout the city Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the question content is not identical, both questions relate to the treatment of non-Muslims under Ottoman Islamic rule. The ground truth MCQ asks about the specific religious communities allowed religious freedoms, while Question 2 asks about the tax paid by non-Muslims in exchange for those freedoms. 

However, among the provided options, Question 2 is the closest match in terms of content and intent.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the late 13th century, Osman I 
established a small beylik, or principality, in what is now Turkey. In just a few generations, this beylik
outmaneuvered more powerful neighbors to become the vast Ottoman empire. What enabled its rapid rise? In Osman’s time, the Anatolian peninsula
was a patchwork of Turkic principalities sandwiched between a crumbling
Byzantine Empire and weakened Sultanate
of the Seljuk of Rum. Osman quickly expanded this territory through a mixture of strategic
political alliances and military conflicts 
with these neighbors, attracting mercenaries first
with the promise of booty, then later through his reputation 
for winning. Osman was the first in a line 
of Ottoman rulers distinguished by their political shrewdness. Often prioritizing political and military
utility over ethnic or religious affinity, they expanded their influence by fighting
along certain sides when needed, and fighting against them 
when the time was right. After Osman’s death his son Orhan established a sophisticated military
organization and tax collection system geared towards funding 
quick territorial expansion. The Ottomans’ first major expansion
was in the Balkans, in southeast Europe. The military employed a mixture
of Turkic warriors and Byzantine and other Balkan Christian converts. They captured thousands 
of young Christian boys from villages from across the Balkans, converted them to Islam, and trained
them to become the backbone of a fierce military elite force
known as the Janissaries. The captured enslaved boys could rise
to the high position of a vizier in the Ottoman government. Rulers of conquered areas were
also allowed, even encouraged, to convert to Islam and take positions
in the Ottoman government. Meanwhile, non-Muslims 
who belonged to Abrahamic religions were allowed religious freedom 
in exchange for a tax known as Jizye, among other strict conditions— for example, they were not allowed
to join the army. By the end of the 14th century, 
the Ottomans had conquered or subordinated most of the Anatolian beyliks 
as well as the Balkans. But in the first half of the 15th century, as Sultan Beyazit I focused
on Western expansion, the Central Asian ruler Timur attacked
from the east. He captured Beyazit and carted
him off in an iron cage, sparking a ten year struggle 
for succession that almost destroyed the Ottoman empire. Sultan Murad II turned this trend around, but fell short of one 
of his loftiest goals: capturing the Byzantine capital,
Constantinople. His son, Sultan Mehmed II, 
or Mehmed the Conqueror, vowed to succeed where his father
had failed. In preparation for the attack 
on Constantinople, he hired a Hungarian engineer 
to forge the largest cannon in the world, used Serbian miners to dig tunnels
under the walls of the city, and ordered his fleet of ships
to be carried overland, attacking the city 
from an unexpected direction. He laid siege to the city 
and in the spring of 1453, Constantinople fell to the Ottomans. It would become the Ottoman capital, 
known by its common Greek name, Istanbul, meaning “to the city.” By the time Mehmed II
conquered Constantinople, the city was a shadow of its former glory. Under Ottoman rule, 
it flourished once again. On an average day in Istanbul, you could
hear people speaking Greek, Turkish, Armenian, Persian, Arabic, Bulgarian,
Albanian, and Serbian. Architects like the famous Sinan
filled the city with splendid mosques and other buildings commissioned
by the sultans. Through Istanbul, the Otttomans brought
commodities like coffee to Europe. They entered a golden age 
of economic growth, territorial acquisition, 
art and architecture. They brought together craftspeople 
from across Europe, Africa, the Middle East and Central Asia to create
a unique blend of cultural innovation. Iznik ceramics, for example, were made using techniques
from China’s Ming dynasty, reimagined with Ottoman motifs. The Ottomans would continue to expand, cementing their political influence
and lucrative trade routes. The empire lasted for more than 600 years 
and, at its peak, stretched from Hungary
to the Persian Gulf, from the Horn of Africa
to the Crimean Peninsula.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Ottoman rulers were often distinguished for their political acumen, often prioritizing ----- when making strategic decisions.
Options: A. Religious affinity, B. Ethnic affinity, C. Political and Military utility, D. None of the above, E. All of the above
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
In the late 13th century, Osman I 
established a small beylik, or principality, in what is now Turkey. In just a few generations, this beylik
outmaneuvered more powerful neighbors to become the vast Ottoman empire. What enabled its rapid rise? In Osman’s time, the Anatolian peninsula
was a patchwork of Turkic principalities sandwiched between a crumbling
Byzantine Empire and weakened Sultanate
of the Seljuk of Rum. Osman quickly expanded this territory through a mixture of strategic
political alliances and military conflicts 
with these neighbors, attracting mercenaries first
with the promise of booty, then later through his reputation 
for winning. Osman was the first in a line 
of Ottoman rulers distinguished by their political shrewdness. Often prioritizing political and military
utility over ethnic or religious affinity, they expanded their influence by fighting
along certain sides when needed, and fighting against them 
when the time was right. After Osman’s death his son Orhan established a sophisticated military
organization and tax collection system geared towards funding 
quick territorial expansion. The Ottomans’ first major expansion
was in the Balkans, in southeast Europe. The military employed a mixture
of Turkic warriors and Byzantine and other Balkan Christian converts. They captured thousands 
of young Christian boys from villages from across the Balkans, converted them to Islam, and trained
them to become the backbone of a fierce military elite force
known as the Janissaries. The captured enslaved boys could rise
to the high position of a vizier in the Ottoman government. Rulers of conquered areas were
also allowed, even encouraged, to convert to Islam and take positions
in the Ottoman government. Meanwhile, non-Muslims 
who belonged to Abrahamic religions were allowed religious freedom 
in exchange for a tax known as Jizye, among other strict conditions— for example, they were not allowed
to join the army. By the end of the 14th century, 
the Ottomans had conquered or subordinated most of the Anatolian beyliks 
as well as the Balkans. But in the first half of the 15th century, as Sultan Beyazit I focused
on Western expansion, the Central Asian ruler Timur attacked
from the east. He captured Beyazit and carted
him off in an iron cage, sparking a ten year struggle 
for succession that almost destroyed the Ottoman empire. Sultan Murad II turned this trend around, but fell short of one 
of his loftiest goals: capturing the Byzantine capital,
Constantinople. His son, Sultan Mehmed II, 
or Mehmed the Conqueror, vowed to succeed where his father
had failed. In preparation for the attack 
on Constantinople, he hired a Hungarian engineer 
to forge the largest cannon in the world, used Serbian miners to dig tunnels
under the walls of the city, and ordered his fleet of ships
to be carried overland, attacking the city 
from an unexpected direction. He laid siege to the city 
and in the spring of 1453, Constantinople fell to the Ottomans. It would become the Ottoman capital, 
known by its common Greek name, Istanbul, meaning “to the city.” By the time Mehmed II
conquered Constantinople, the city was a shadow of its former glory. Under Ottoman rule, 
it flourished once again. On an average day in Istanbul, you could
hear people speaking Greek, Turkish, Armenian, Persian, Arabic, Bulgarian,
Albanian, and Serbian. Architects like the famous Sinan
filled the city with splendid mosques and other buildings commissioned
by the sultans. Through Istanbul, the Otttomans brought
commodities like coffee to Europe. They entered a golden age 
of economic growth, territorial acquisition, 
art and architecture. They brought together craftspeople 
from across Europe, Africa, the Middle East and Central Asia to create
a unique blend of cultural innovation. Iznik ceramics, for example, were made using techniques
from China’s Ming dynasty, reimagined with Ottoman motifs. The Ottomans would continue to expand, cementing their political influence
and lucrative trade routes. The empire lasted for more than 600 years 
and, at its peak, stretched from Hungary
to the Persian Gulf, from the Horn of Africa
to the Crimean Peninsula.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Janissaries were an Elite military fighting force made up of
Options: A. Christian men from the Balkans, B. Muslim boys trained in Istanbul, C. Christian boys converted and trained in Istanbul, D. Muslim men who originated from Christian families, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the founder of the Ottoman Empire? Options: A. Sultan Beyazit I, B. Sultan Murad II, C. Osman I, D. Timur Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the name of the tax that non-Muslims belonging to Abrahamic religions had to pay in exchange for religious freedom? Options: A. Jizya, B. Jizye, C. Zakat, D. Ushr Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the name of the elite military force that was formed by the Ottomans using captured Christian boys? Options: A. Janissaries, B. Mamluks, C. Spahis, D. Akıncılar Correct Option: A
Question 4: Who was the Central Asia ruler who attacked the Ottoman Empire from the east and captured Sultan Beyazit I? Options: A. Timur, B. Tamerlane, C. Genghis Khan, D. Babur Correct Option: A

Question 7: What architectural style was popular during the Ottoman Empire, characterized by the use of domes and minarets? Options: A. Islamic architecture, B. Ottoman architecture, C. Byzantine architecture, D. Seljuk architecture Correct Option: B
Question 8: How did the Ottomans expand their influence in the Balkans? Options: A. By capturing thousands of young Christian boys from villages across the Balkans, converting them to Islam, and training them to become soldiers, B. By establishing trade routes and economic ties, C. By forming alliances with local rulers and converting local Christians to Islam, D. By relying on their naval power Correct Option: A

It marked the beginning of the Ottoman Empire's expansion into Europe, C. It marked the end of the Byzantine Empire, D. It led to the decline of the Byzantine Empire Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the impact of the Ottoman Empire's expansion on the city of Istanbul? Options: A. It led to the destruction of the city's infrastructure, B. It led to the decline of the city's population and economy, C. It resulted in the spread of Islam throughout the city Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the late 13th century, Osman I 
established a small beylik, or principality, in what is now Turkey. In just a few generations, this beylik
outmaneuvered more powerful neighbors to become the vast Ottoman empire. What enabled its rapid rise? In Osman’s time, the Anatolian peninsula
was a patchwork of Turkic principalities sandwiched between a crumbling
Byzantine Empire and weakened Sultanate
of the Seljuk of Rum. Osman quickly expanded this territory through a mixture of strategic
political alliances and military conflicts 
with these neighbors, attracting mercenaries first
with the promise of booty, then later through his reputation 
for winning. Osman was the first in a line 
of Ottoman rulers distinguished by their political shrewdness. Often prioritizing political and military
utility over ethnic or religious affinity, they expanded their influence by fighting
along certain sides when needed, and fighting against them 
when the time was right. After Osman’s death his son Orhan established a sophisticated military
organization and tax collection system geared towards funding 
quick territorial expansion. The Ottomans’ first major expansion
was in the Balkans, in southeast Europe. The military employed a mixture
of Turkic warriors and Byzantine and other Balkan Christian converts. They captured thousands 
of young Christian boys from villages from across the Balkans, converted them to Islam, and trained
them to become the backbone of a fierce military elite force
known as the Janissaries. The captured enslaved boys could rise
to the high position of a vizier in the Ottoman government. Rulers of conquered areas were
also allowed, even encouraged, to convert to Islam and take positions
in the Ottoman government. Meanwhile, non-Muslims 
who belonged to Abrahamic religions were allowed religious freedom 
in exchange for a tax known as Jizye, among other strict conditions— for example, they were not allowed
to join the army. By the end of the 14th century, 
the Ottomans had conquered or subordinated most of the Anatolian beyliks 
as well as the Balkans. But in the first half of the 15th century, as Sultan Beyazit I focused
on Western expansion, the Central Asian ruler Timur attacked
from the east. He captured Beyazit and carted
him off in an iron cage, sparking a ten year struggle 
for succession that almost destroyed the Ottoman empire. Sultan Murad II turned this trend around, but fell short of one 
of his loftiest goals: capturing the Byzantine capital,
Constantinople. His son, Sultan Mehmed II, 
or Mehmed the Conqueror, vowed to succeed where his father
had failed. In preparation for the attack 
on Constantinople, he hired a Hungarian engineer 
to forge the largest cannon in the world, used Serbian miners to dig tunnels
under the walls of the city, and ordered his fleet of ships
to be carried overland, attacking the city 
from an unexpected direction. He laid siege to the city 
and in the spring of 1453, Constantinople fell to the Ottomans. It would become the Ottoman capital, 
known by its common Greek name, Istanbul, meaning “to the city.” By the time Mehmed II
conquered Constantinople, the city was a shadow of its former glory. Under Ottoman rule, 
it flourished once again. On an average day in Istanbul, you could
hear people speaking Greek, Turkish, Armenian, Persian, Arabic, Bulgarian,
Albanian, and Serbian. Architects like the famous Sinan
filled the city with splendid mosques and other buildings commissioned
by the sultans. Through Istanbul, the Otttomans brought
commodities like coffee to Europe. They entered a golden age 
of economic growth, territorial acquisition,

from across Europe, Africa, the Middle East and Central Asia to create
a unique blend of cultural innovation. Iznik ceramics, for example, were made using techniques
from China’s Ming dynasty, reimagined with Ottoman motifs. The Ottomans would continue to expand, cementing their political influence
and lucrative trade routes. The empire lasted for more than 600 years 
and, at its peak, stretched from Hungary
to the Persian Gulf, from the Horn of Africa
to the Crimean Peninsula.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The name of the Ottoman capital, Istanbul, comes from
Options: A. The Turkish word for Constantinople, B. The Arabic word for Constantinople, C. A common Greek form of referring “to the city”, D. The name of the Ottoman hero “Estani”, E. None of the Above
Correct Option: C

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. But among the provided options, Question 5 is the closest match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the late 13th century, Osman I 
established a small beylik, or principality, in what is now Turkey. In just a few generations, this beylik
outmaneuvered more powerful neighbors to become the vast Ottoman empire. What enabled its rapid rise? In Osman’s time, the Anatolian peninsula
was a patchwork of Turkic principalities sandwiched between a crumbling
Byzantine Empire and weakened Sultanate
of the Seljuk of Rum. Osman quickly expanded this territory through a mixture of strategic
political alliances and military conflicts 
with these neighbors, attracting mercenaries first
with the promise of booty, then later through his reputation 
for winning. Osman was the first in a line 
of Ottoman rulers distinguished by their political shrewdness. Often prioritizing political and military
utility over ethnic or religious affinity, they expanded their influence by fighting
along certain sides when needed, and fighting against them 
when the time was right. After Osman’s death his son Orhan established a sophisticated military
organization and tax collection system geared towards funding 
quick territorial expansion. The Ottomans’ first major expansion
was in the Balkans, in southeast Europe. The military employed a mixture
of Turkic warriors and Byzantine and other Balkan Christian converts. They captured thousands 
of young Christian boys from villages from across the Balkans, converted them to Islam, and trained
them to become the backbone of a fierce military elite force
known as the Janissaries. The captured enslaved boys could rise
to the high position of a vizier in the Ottoman government. Rulers of conquered areas were
also allowed, even encouraged, to convert to Islam and take positions
in the Ottoman government. Meanwhile, non-Muslims 
who belonged to Abrahamic religions were allowed religious freedom 
in exchange for a tax known as Jizye, among other strict conditions— for example, they were not allowed
to join the army. By the end of the 14th century, 
the Ottomans had conquered or subordinated most of the Anatolian beyliks 
as well as the Balkans. But in the first half of the 15th century, as Sultan Beyazit I focused
on Western expansion, the Central Asian ruler Timur attacked
from the east. He captured Beyazit and carted
him off in an iron cage, sparking a ten year struggle 
for succession that almost destroyed the Ottoman empire. Sultan Murad II turned this trend around, but fell short of one 
of his loftiest goals: capturing the Byzantine capital,
Constantinople. His son, Sultan Mehmed II, 
or Mehmed the Conqueror, vowed to succeed where his father
had failed. In preparation for the attack 
on Constantinople, he hired a Hungarian engineer 
to forge the largest cannon in the world, used Serbian miners to dig tunnels
under the walls of the city, and ordered his fleet of ships
to be carried overland, attacking the city 
from an unexpected direction. He laid siege to the city 
and in the spring of 1453, Constantinople fell to the Ottomans. It would become the Ottoman capital, 
known by its common Greek name, Istanbul, meaning “to the city.” By the time Mehmed II
conquered Constantinople, the city was a shadow of its former glory. Under Ottoman rule, 
it flourished once again. On an average day in Istanbul, you could
hear people speaking Greek, Turkish, Armenian, Persian, Arabic, Bulgarian,
Albanian, and Serbian. Architects like the famous Sinan
filled the city with splendid mosques and other buildings commissioned
by the sultans. Through Istanbul, the Otttomans brought
commodities like coffee to Europe. They entered a golden age 
of economic growth, territorial acquisition, 
art and architecture. They brought together craftspeople 
from across Europe, Africa, the Middle East and Central Asia to create
a unique blend of cultural innovation. Iznik ceramics, for example, were made using techniques
from China’s Ming dynasty, reimagined with Ottoman motifs. The Ottomans would continue to expand, cementing their political influence
and lucrative trade routes. The empire lasted for more than 600 years 
and, at its peak, stretched from Hungary
to the Persian Gulf, from the Horn of Africa
to the Crimean Peninsula.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: At its peak territorial expansion, the Ottoman Empire covered
Options: A. All of Asia, B. Southeastern Europe and western Asia, C. North Africa and the Red Sea Basin, D. A and B are correct, E. B and C are correct
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the founder of the Ottoman Empire? Options: A. Sultan Beyazit I, B. Sultan Murad II, C. Osman I, D. Timur Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the name of the tax that non-Muslims belonging to Abrahamic religions had to pay in exchange for religious freedom? Options: A. Jizya, B. Jizye, C. Zakat, D. Ushr Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the name of the elite military force that was formed by the Ottomans using captured Christian boys? Options: A. Janissaries, B. Mamluks, C. Spahis, D. Akıncılar Correct Option: A
Question 4: Who was the Central Asia ruler who attacked the Ottoman Empire from the east and captured Sultan Beyazit I? Options: A. Timur, B. Tamerlane, C. Genghis Khan, D. Babur Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the name of the city that the Ottomans conquered in 1453, which became their capital? Options: A. Constantinople, B. Istanbul, C. Edirne, D. Bursa Correct Option: A
Question 6: Who was the Hungarian engineer who forged the largest cannon in the world for Sultan Mehmed II? Options: A. Orban, B. Urbain, C. Urban, D. Ural Correct Option: A
Question 7: What architectural style was popular during the Ottoman Empire, characterized by the use of domes and minarets? Options: A. Islamic architecture, B. Ottoman architecture, C. Byzantine architecture, D. Seljuk architecture Correct Option: B
Question 8: How did the Ottomans expand their influence in the Balkans? Options: A. By capturing thousands of young Christian boys from villages across the Balkans, converting them to Islam, and training them to become soldiers, B. By establishing trade routes and economic ties, C. By forming alliances with local rulers and converting local Christians to Islam, D. By relying on their naval power Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the significance of the capture of Constantinople by the Ottomans in 1453? Options: A. It marked the end of the Ottoman Empire's golden age, B. It marked the beginning of the Ottoman Empire's expansion into Europe, C. It marked the end of the Byzantine Empire, D. It led to the decline of the Byzantine Empire Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the impact of the Ottoman Empire's expansion on the city of Istanbul? Options: A. It led to the destruction of the city's infrastructure, B. It led to the decline of the city's population and economy, C. It brought together people from across Europe, Africa, the Middle East, and Central Asia, creating a unique blend of cultural innovation, D. It resulted in the spread of Islam throughout the city Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that partially relates to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Princess Savitri of the Madra Kingdom
was as benevolent, brilliant, and bright as the Sun God she was named for. Her grace was known throughout the land, and many powerful princes and wealthy
merchants flocked to her family’s palace to seek her hand in marriage. But upon witnessing her blinding splendor
in person, the men lost their nerve. Unimpressed with these suitors, the princess determined
to find a husband herself. Mounting her golden chariot, 
she travelled through rolling deserts, glittering cities 
and snow-capped mountains— rejecting many men along the way. Eventually, Savitri ventured 
deep into the jungle, where she met a young man 
chopping wood. His name was Satyavan, and like her,
he loved the tranquil forest— but the princess saw he was not at peace. After talking for hours, Satyavan told
her of his plight. His parents had once been wealthy rulers, until his father was blinded 
and overthrown in a violent coup. Now Satyavan worked tirelessly 
to support their meager new life. His determination and devotion
moved the princess. As they gazed into each other’s eyes,
she knew she’d finally found an equal. Savitri rushed home to tell
her father the good news, only to find him conversing with Narada a traveling sage and wisest messenger 
of the Gods. At first her father was thrilled
to learn of Satyavan, but Narada revealed a tragic prophecy:
her betrothed had only a year to live. Savitri’s blood ran cold. She’d waited so long to find her partner—
was she already doomed to lose him? The princess would not accept these terms. She swore before Narada, her family, and Savitr himself that she would
never marry another. Satyavan was her one true love,
and their fates were entwined forever. Moved by her powerful words, the sage told the princess to follow
an ancient spiritual regimen. With regular prayer, periods of fasting, and preparation of special
herbs and plants, she might be able to prolong
Satyavan’s life. After a simple wedding, the couple
returned to the jungle to live in keeping with the sage’s instructions. This modest existence was a far cry
from her lavish upbringing, but they were happy in each other’s
company. A year passed, and the fated day arrived. On their first anniversary, 
the sun grew horribly hot, and Satyavan’s brow began to burn, Savitri barely had time to drag 
him into the shade, before he grew still and cold. Through her tears, the princess
saw an immense figure on the horizon. This was Yamraj, the God of Death, come to escort Satyavan’s soul 
to the afterlife. But Savitri was not giving up yet. She followed the god for hours
in the beating sun. Yamraj thundered at the princess
to leave him in peace. But even as her feet bled and throat
burned, Savitri would not turn back. Eventually, Yamraj paused. He would grant her one wish 
as reward for her persistence, but she couldn’t ask
for her husband’s life. Without hesitating, Savitri asked the God 
to restore her father in-law’s sight. The wish was granted, and Yamraj rode on. But still Savitri’s footsteps
echoed behind him. Exasperated, the God granted
her a second wish. This time, she asked for Satyavan’s
kingdom to be restored. Again the wish was granted, and Yamraj began his descent 
into his subterranean kingdom. But when he glanced back, he was astounded to see 
the bedraggled princess stumbling along. He’d never seen such devotion to the dead, and he honored her dedication
with one final wish. Savitri wished to be the mother
of many children. The God agreed, and waved to dismiss her. But the princess only repeated the vow
she’d made one year earlier: her fate was forever entwined
with Satyavan. How could she bear many children,
if Yamraj would not return her husband? Hearing this clever question the god
relented, knowing he’d been beaten. With Yamraj’s blessing and respect,
Satyavan was returned to Savitri, and the two walked back 
to the land of the living, united in a love that not even
death could destroy.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Savitri left the palace because:
Options: A. She wanted to get away from her parents, B. She wanted an adventure, C. She didn’t want to be a princess any more, D. She wanted to live in the jungle
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Princess Savitri named after? Options: A. The God of Wealth, B. The Sun God, C. The God of Death, D. The God of Wisdom Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why did the men who sought Princess Savitri's hand in marriage lose their nerve? Options: A. They were intimidated by her wealth, B. They were unimpressed by her beauty, C. They were afraid of her blinding splendor, D. They were intimidated by her intelligence Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the prophecy that Narada revealed to Princess Savitri about her betrothed, Satyavan? Options: A. He would live a long and happy life, B. He would become a great king, C. He had only a year to live, D. He would be rich and successful Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the spiritual regimen that Narada told Princess Savitri to follow in order to prolong Satyavan's life? Options: A. Regular prayer, periods of fasting, and preparation of special herbs and plants, B. Meditation and yoga, C. Reading and writing, D. Singing and dancing Correct Option: A
Question 5: Why did Princess Savitri follow Yamraj for hours in the beating sun? Options: A. She wanted to get to the afterlife, B. She wanted to see Yamraj's kingdom, C. She wanted to prolong Satyavan's life, D. She wanted to show her devotion to Satyavan Correct Option: D
Question 6: What was the first wish that Princess Savitri asked Yamraj to grant? Options: A. To restore her father-in-law's sight, B. To bring Satyavan back to life, C. To become the queen of the afterlife, D. To have many children Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why did Yamraj grant Princess Savitri a second wish? Options: A. He was impressed by her beauty, B. He was moved by her devotion, C. He was forced to by a rule, D. He was bribed Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the final wish that Princess Savitri asked Yamraj to grant? Options: A. To bring Satyavan back to life, B. To have many children, C. To become the queen of the afterlife, D. To go to the afterlife with Satyavan Correct Option: B
Question 9: Why did Yamraj finally grant Princess Savitri's wish to have many children? Options: A. He was impressed by her beauty, B. He was moved by her devotion, C. He was forced to by a rule, D. He was bribed Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the outcome of Princess Savitri's final wish? Options: A. Satyavan was brought back to life, B. Princess Savitri became the queen of the afterlife, C. Princess Savitri had many children, and Satyavan was returned to her, D. Yamraj was punished Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that comes closest to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent.

The ground truth MCQ asks why Savitri left the palace, and the correct option is that she wanted an adventure. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 2 comes closest in terms of intent. It asks why the men who sought Princess Savitri's hand in marriage lost their nerve, and the correct option is that they were afraid of her blinding splendor. This question is related to the events that led to Savitri leaving the palace, as she was unimpressed with the suitors and decided to find a husband herself.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is more similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, I would suggest Question 5. It asks why Princess Savitri followed Yamraj for hours in the beating sun, and the correct option is that she wanted to show her devotion to Satyavan. This question shows Savitri's determination and strong will, which is similar to the intent behind the ground truth MCQ, where Savitri leaves the palace to find a husband herself.

But since neither of these questions is a direct match, I would recommend creating a new generated MCQ that directly asks why Savitri left the palace, with options that match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that Question 5 is the most similar generated MCQ, but with a low confidence score.

never marry another. Satyavan was her one true love,
and their fates were entwined forever. Moved by her powerful words, the sage told the princess to follow
an ancient spiritual regimen. With regular prayer, periods of fasting, and preparation of special
herbs and plants, she might be able to prolong

returned to the jungle to live in keeping with the sage’s instructions. This modest existence was a far cry

of many children. The God agreed, and waved to dismiss her. But the princess only repeated the vow
she’d made one year earlier: her fate was forever entwined
with Satyavan. How could she bear many children,
if Yamraj would not return her husband? Hearing this clever question the god
relented, knowing he’d been beaten. With Yamraj’s blessing and respect,
Satyavan was returned to Savitri, and the two walked back 
to the land of the living, united in a love that not even
death could destroy.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: At the wedding, Narada told Savitri that:

Question 7: Why did Yamraj grant Princess Savitri a second wish? Options: A. He was impressed by her beauty, B. He was moved by her devotion, C. He was forced to by a rule, D. He was bribed Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the final wish that Princess Savitri asked Yamraj to grant? Options: A. To bring Satyavan back to life, B. To have many children, C. To become the queen of the afterlife, D. To go to the afterlife with Satyavan Correct Option: B
Question 9: Why did Yamraj finally grant Princess Savitri's wish to have many children? Options: A. He was impressed by her beauty, B. He was moved by her devotion, C. He was forced to by a rule, D. He was bribed Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the outcome of Princess Savitri's final wish? Options: A. Satyavan was brought back to life, B. Princess Savitri became the queen of the afterlife, C. Princess Savitri had many children, and Satyavan was returned to her, D. Yamraj was punished Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Princess Savitri of the Madra Kingdom
was as benevolent, brilliant, and bright as the Sun God she was named for. Her grace was known throughout the land, and many powerful princes and wealthy
merchants flocked to her family’s palace to seek her hand in marriage. But upon witnessing her blinding splendor
in person, the men lost their nerve. Unimpressed with these suitors, the princess determined
to find a husband herself. Mounting her golden chariot, 
she travelled through rolling deserts, glittering cities 
and snow-capped mountains— rejecting many men along the way. Eventually, Savitri ventured 
deep into the jungle, where she met a young man 
chopping wood. His name was Satyavan, and like her,
he loved the tranquil forest— but the princess saw he was not at peace. After talking for hours, Satyavan told
her of his plight. His parents had once been wealthy rulers, until his father was blinded 
and overthrown in a violent coup. Now Satyavan worked tirelessly 
to support their meager new life. His determination and devotion
moved the princess. As they gazed into each other’s eyes,
she knew she’d finally found an equal. Savitri rushed home to tell
her father the good news, only to find him conversing with Narada a traveling sage and wisest messenger 
of the Gods. At first her father was thrilled
to learn of Satyavan, but Narada revealed a tragic prophecy:
her betrothed had only a year to live. Savitri’s blood ran cold. She’d waited so long to find her partner—
was she already doomed to lose him? The princess would not accept these terms. She swore before Narada, her family, and Savitr himself that she would
never marry another. Satyavan was her one true love,
and their fates were entwined forever. Moved by her powerful words, the sage told the princess to follow
an ancient spiritual regimen. With regular prayer, periods of fasting, and preparation of special
herbs and plants, she might be able to prolong
Satyavan’s life. After a simple wedding, the couple
returned to the jungle to live in keeping with the sage’s instructions. This modest existence was a far cry
from her lavish upbringing, but they were happy in each other’s
company. A year passed, and the fated day arrived. On their first anniversary, 
the sun grew horribly hot, and Satyavan’s brow began to burn, Savitri barely had time to drag 
him into the shade, before he grew still and cold. Through her tears, the princess
saw an immense figure on the horizon. This was Yamraj, the God of Death, come to escort Satyavan’s soul 
to the afterlife. But Savitri was not giving up yet. She followed the god for hours
in the beating sun. Yamraj thundered at the princess
to leave him in peace. But even as her feet bled and throat
burned, Savitri would not turn back. Eventually, Yamraj paused. He would grant her one wish 
as reward for her persistence, but she couldn’t ask
for her husband’s life. Without hesitating, Savitri asked the God 
to restore her father in-law’s sight. The wish was granted, and Yamraj rode on. But still Savitri’s footsteps
echoed behind him. Exasperated, the God granted
her a second wish. This time, she asked for Satyavan’s
kingdom to be restored. Again the wish was granted, and Yamraj began his descent 
into his subterranean kingdom. But when he glanced back, he was astounded to see 
the bedraggled princess stumbling along. He’d never seen such devotion to the dead, and he honored her dedication
with one final wish. Savitri wished to be the mother
of many children. The God agreed, and waved to dismiss her. But the princess only repeated the vow
she’d made one year earlier: her fate was forever entwined
with Satyavan. How could she bear many children,
if Yamraj would not return her husband? Hearing this clever question the god
relented, knowing he’d been beaten. With Yamraj’s blessing and respect,
Satyavan was returned to Savitri, and the two walked back 
to the land of the living, united in a love that not even
death could destroy.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Yamraj is the God of ___ and he rides on a ___
Options: A. Death; water buffalo, B. Love; horse, C. War; lion, D. Discord, wolf
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
Princess Savitri of the Madra Kingdom
was as benevolent, brilliant, and bright as the Sun God she was named for. Her grace was known throughout the land, and many powerful princes and wealthy
merchants flocked to her family’s palace to seek her hand in marriage. But upon witnessing her blinding splendor
in person, the men lost their nerve. Unimpressed with these suitors, the princess determined
to find a husband herself. Mounting her golden chariot, 
she travelled through rolling deserts, glittering cities 
and snow-capped mountains— rejecting many men along the way. Eventually, Savitri ventured 
deep into the jungle, where she met a young man 
chopping wood. His name was Satyavan, and like her,
he loved the tranquil forest— but the princess saw he was not at peace. After talking for hours, Satyavan told
her of his plight. His parents had once been wealthy rulers, until his father was blinded 
and overthrown in a violent coup. Now Satyavan worked tirelessly 
to support their meager new life. His determination and devotion
moved the princess. As they gazed into each other’s eyes,
she knew she’d finally found an equal. Savitri rushed home to tell
her father the good news, only to find him conversing with Narada a traveling sage and wisest messenger 
of the Gods. At first her father was thrilled
to learn of Satyavan, but Narada revealed a tragic prophecy:
her betrothed had only a year to live. Savitri’s blood ran cold. She’d waited so long to find her partner—
was she already doomed to lose him? The princess would not accept these terms. She swore before Narada, her family, and Savitr himself that she would
never marry another. Satyavan was her one true love,
and their fates were entwined forever. Moved by her powerful words, the sage told the princess to follow
an ancient spiritual regimen. With regular prayer, periods of fasting, and preparation of special
herbs and plants, she might be able to prolong
Satyavan’s life. After a simple wedding, the couple
returned to the jungle to live in keeping with the sage’s instructions. This modest existence was a far cry
from her lavish upbringing, but they were happy in each other’s
company. A year passed, and the fated day arrived. On their first anniversary, 
the sun grew horribly hot, and Satyavan’s brow began to burn, Savitri barely had time to drag 
him into the shade, before he grew still and cold. Through her tears, the princess
saw an immense figure on the horizon. This was Yamraj, the God of Death, come to escort Satyavan’s soul 
to the afterlife. But Savitri was not giving up yet. She followed the god for hours
in the beating sun. Yamraj thundered at the princess
to leave him in peace. But even as her feet bled and throat
burned, Savitri would not turn back. Eventually, Yamraj paused. He would grant her one wish 
as reward for her persistence, but she couldn’t ask
for her husband’s life. Without hesitating, Savitri asked the God 
to restore her father in-law’s sight. The wish was granted, and Yamraj rode on. But still Savitri’s footsteps
echoed behind him. Exasperated, the God granted
her a second wish. This time, she asked for Satyavan’s
kingdom to be restored. Again the wish was granted, and Yamraj began his descent 
into his subterranean kingdom. But when he glanced back, he was astounded to see 
the bedraggled princess stumbling along. He’d never seen such devotion to the dead, and he honored her dedication
with one final wish. Savitri wished to be the mother
of many children. The God agreed, and waved to dismiss her. But the princess only repeated the vow
she’d made one year earlier: her fate was forever entwined
with Satyavan. How could she bear many children,
if Yamraj would not return her husband? Hearing this clever question the god
relented, knowing he’d been beaten. With Yamraj’s blessing and respect,
Satyavan was returned to Savitri, and the two walked back 
to the land of the living, united in a love that not even
death could destroy.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
How many people does it take to make
a cup of coffee? For many of us, all it takes is a short
walk and a quick pour. But this simple staple is the result 
of a globe-spanning process whose cost and complexity are far greater
than you might imagine. It begins in a place like the remote
Colombian town of Pitalito. Here, family farms have clear cut 
local forests to make room for neat rows of Coffea trees. These shrub-like plants 
were first domesticated in Ethiopia and are now cultivated throughout
equatorial regions. Each shrub is filled with small berries
called "coffee cherries." Since fruits on the same branch 
can ripen at different times, they’re best picked by hand, but each farm has its own method
for processing the fruit. In Pitalito, harvesters toil 
from dawn to dusk at high altitudes, often picking over 25 kilograms per shift
for very low wages. The workers deliver their picked cherries
to the wet mill. This machine separates the seeds
from the fruit, and then sorts them by density. The heaviest, most flavorful seeds 
sink to the bottom of the mill, where they’re collected 
and taken to ferment in a tub of water for one or two days. Then, workers wash off the remaining fruit
and put the seeds out to dry. Some farms use machines for this process, but in Pitalito, seeds are spread
onto large mesh racks. Over the next three weeks, 
workers rake the seeds regularly to ensure they dry evenly. Once the coffee beans are dry, a truck takes them to a nearby mill
with several specialized machines. An air blower re-sorts the seeds 
by density, an assortment of sieves filter 
them by size, and an optical scanner sorts by color. At this point, professionals called
Q-graders select samples of beans to roast and brew. In a process called "cupping," 
they evaluate the coffee’s taste, aroma, and mouthfeel to determine its quality. These experts give the beans a grade,
and get them ready to ship. Workers load burlap sacks 
containing up to 70 kilograms of dried and sorted coffee beans
onto steel shipping containers, each able to carry 
up to 21 metric tons of coffee. From tropical ports, cargo ships 
crewed by over 25 people transport coffee around the world But no country imports more coffee
than the United States, with New York City alone consuming
millions of cups every day. After the long journey 
from Colombia to New Jersey, our coffee beans pass through customs. Once dockworkers unload the container, a fleet of eighteen-wheelers transport 
the coffee to a nearby warehouse, and then to a roastery. Here the beans go into a roasting machine,
stirred by a metallic arm and heated by a gas-powered fire. Nearby sensors monitor the coffee’s
moisture level, chemical stability, and temperature, while trained coffee
engineers manually adjust these levels throughout the twelve-minute
roasting cycle. This process releases oil within the seed, transforming the seeds into grindable,
brewable beans with a dark brown color and rich aroma. After roasting, workers pack the beans
into five-pound bags, which a fleet of vans deliver to cafes
and stores across the city. The coffee is now so close 
you can smell it, but it needs more help 
for the final stretch. Each coffee company has a head buyer who carefully selects beans 
from all over the world. Logistics teams manage 
bean delivery routes, and brave baristas across the city
serve this caffeinated elixir to scores of hurried customers. All in all, it takes hundreds of people
to get coffee to its intended destination— and that’s not counting everyone
maintaining the infrastructure that makes the journey possible. Many of these individuals work 
for low pay in dangerous conditions— and some aren’t paid at all. So while we might marvel at the global
network behind this commodity, let’s make sure we don’t value 
the final product more than the people who make it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In which country was the Coffee tree first domesticated?
Options: A. Ethiopia, B. Kenya, C. Somalia, D. Sudan
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the primary function of the wet mill in the coffee production process? Options: A. To separate seeds from the fruit and sort them by density, B. To ferment coffee beans, C. To dry coffee seeds, D. To roast coffee beans Correct Option: A
Question 2: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of coffee production in Pitalito, Colombia. Options: A. Coffee cherries are picked, separated from the fruit, and then dried, B. Coffee beans are picked, fermented, and then dried, C. Coffee seeds are separated from the fruit, washed, and then dried, D. Coffee cherries are picked, separated from the fruit, fermented, and then dried Correct Option: D
Question 3: **Application**: If you were a coffee farmer in Pitalito, how would you ensure that your coffee seeds dry evenly? Options: A. By spreading them out on a large mesh rack and raking them regularly, B. By using a machine to dry them, C. By covering them with a tarp, D. By leaving them outside in the sun Correct Option: A
Question 4: **Analysis**: What are the main differences between the coffee production process in Pitalito and the process in a nearby mill? Options: A. The use of manual labor vs. machines, B. The type of coffee beans used, C. The location of the production process, D. The quality of the final product Correct Option: A
Question 5: **Synthesis**: How do the various stages of the coffee production process contribute to the final product? Options: A. Each stage adds a new ingredient, B. Each stage changes the flavor and aroma of the coffee, C. Each stage transforms the coffee from a raw material to a finished product, D. Each stage is unnecessary and can be skipped Correct Option: C
Question 6: **Evaluation**: What are the social implications of the coffee production process, particularly in Pitalito? Options: A. Low wages and poor working conditions for farmers and laborers, B. High wages and good working conditions, C. No social implications, D. The coffee production process is sustainable and environmentally friendly Correct Option: A
Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the purpose of Q-graders in the coffee production process? Options: A. To evaluate the quality of the coffee, B. To select samples of beans to roast and brew, C. To sort coffee beans by size and color, D. To dry coffee seeds Correct Option: A
Question 8: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of roasting coffee beans. Options: A. The beans are heated in a machine to release oil, B. The beans are stirred by a metallic arm and heated by a gas-powered fire, C. The beans are sorted by size and color, D. The beans are ground and brewed Correct Option: B
Question 9: **Application**: If you would manage bean delivery routes? Options: A. By using a mapping app to optimize routes, B. By hiring a team of drivers to deliver the beans, C. By using a machine to sort and pack the beans, D. By leaving the beans at the warehouse Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation**: What are the environmental implications of the coffee production process, particularly in terms of transportation? Options: A. The use of fossil fuels contributes to climate change, B. The production process is sustainable and environmentally friendly, C. The transportation process is not significant enough to have an impact, D. The coffee production process does not have any environmental implications Correct Option: A
Question 11: **Knowledge**: What is the primary function of an optical scanner in the coffee production process? Options: A. To sort coffee beans by size and color, B. To evaluate the quality of the coffee, C. To dry coffee seeds, D. To separate seeds from the fruit Correct Option: A
Question 12: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of cupping coffee. Options: A. The coffee is roasted, ground, and then brewed, B. The coffee is evaluated for its taste, aroma, and mouthfeel, C. The coffee is sorted by size and color, D. The coffee is dried and then packaged Correct Option: B
Question 13: **Knowledge**: What is the role of a head buyer in the coffee production process? Options: A. To select beans from all over the world, B. To evaluate the quality of the coffee, C. To sort coffee beans by size and color, D. To select samples of beans to roast and brew Correct Option: A
Question 14: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of shipping coffee from tropical ports to the United States. Options: A. The coffee is transported by cargo ships crewed by over 25 people, B. The coffee is transported by airplanes, C. The coffee is transported by trucks, D. The coffee is transported by trains Correct Option: A
Question 15: **Application**: If you were a dockworker, how would you unload a container of coffee from a cargo ship? Options: A. By using a crane to lift the container off the ship, B. By using a forklift to move the container off the ship, C. By using a machine to sort and pack the coffee, D. By leaving the coffee on the ship Correct Option: A
Question 16: **Evaluation**: What are the social implications of the coffee production process, particularly in terms of labor practices? Options: A. Low wages and poor working conditions for farmers and laborers, B. High wages and good working conditions, C. No social implications, D. The coffee production process is sustainable and environmentally friendly Correct Option: A
Question 17: **Knowledge**: What is the primary function of a Q-grader in the coffee production process? Options: A. To evaluate the quality of the coffee, B. To select samples of beans to roast and brew, C. To sort coffee beans by size and color, D. To dry coffee seeds Correct Option: A
Question 18: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of roasting coffee beans. Options: A. The beans are heated in a machine to release oil, B. The beans are stirred by a metallic arm and heated by a gas-powered fire, C. The beans are sorted by size and color, D. The beans are ground and brewed Correct Option: B
Question 19: **Application**: If you would manage bean delivery routes? Options: A. By using a mapping app to optimize routes, B. By hiring a team of drivers to deliver the beans, C. By using a machine to sort and pack the coffee, D. By leaving the beans at the warehouse Correct Option: A
Question 20: **Evaluation**: What are the environmental implications of the coffee production process, particularly in terms of transportation? Options: A. The use of fossil fuels contributes to climate change, B. The production process is sustainable and environmentally friendly, C. The transportation process is not significant enough to have an impact, D. The coffee production process does not have any environmental implications Correct Option: A

Matching Response:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
How many people does it take to make
a cup of coffee? For many of us, all it takes is a short
walk and a quick pour. But this simple staple is the result 
of a globe-spanning process whose cost and complexity are far greater
than you might imagine. It begins in a place like the remote
Colombian town of Pitalito. Here, family farms have clear cut 
local forests to make room for neat rows of Coffea trees. These shrub-like plants 
were first domesticated in Ethiopia and are now cultivated throughout
equatorial regions. Each shrub is filled with small berries
called "coffee cherries." Since fruits on the same branch 
can ripen at different times, they’re best picked by hand, but each farm has its own method
for processing the fruit. In Pitalito, harvesters toil 
from dawn to dusk at high altitudes, often picking over 25 kilograms per shift
for very low wages. The workers deliver their picked cherries
to the wet mill. This machine separates the seeds
from the fruit, and then sorts them by density. The heaviest, most flavorful seeds 
sink to the bottom of the mill, where they’re collected 
and taken to ferment in a tub of water for one or two days. Then, workers wash off the remaining fruit
and put the seeds out to dry. Some farms use machines for this process, but in Pitalito, seeds are spread
onto large mesh racks. Over the next three weeks, 
workers rake the seeds regularly to ensure they dry evenly. Once the coffee beans are dry, a truck takes them to a nearby mill
with several specialized machines. An air blower re-sorts the seeds 
by density, an assortment of sieves filter 
them by size, and an optical scanner sorts by color. At this point, professionals called
Q-graders select samples of beans to roast and brew. In a process called "cupping," 
they evaluate the coffee’s taste, aroma, and mouthfeel to determine its quality. These experts give the beans a grade,
and get them ready to ship. Workers load burlap sacks 
containing up to 70 kilograms of dried and sorted coffee beans
onto steel shipping containers, each able to carry 
up to 21 metric tons of coffee. From tropical ports, cargo ships 
crewed by over 25 people transport coffee around the world But no country imports more coffee
than the United States, with New York City alone consuming
millions of cups every day. After the long journey 
from Colombia to New Jersey, our coffee beans pass through customs. Once dockworkers unload the container, a fleet of eighteen-wheelers transport 
the coffee to a nearby warehouse, and then to a roastery. Here the beans go into a roasting machine,
stirred by a metallic arm and heated by a gas-powered fire. Nearby sensors monitor the coffee’s
moisture level, chemical stability, and temperature, while trained coffee
engineers manually adjust these levels throughout the twelve-minute
roasting cycle. This process releases oil within the seed, transforming the seeds into grindable,
brewable beans with a dark brown color and rich aroma. After roasting, workers pack the beans
into five-pound bags, which a fleet of vans deliver to cafes
and stores across the city. The coffee is now so close 
you can smell it, but it needs more help 
for the final stretch. Each coffee company has a head buyer who carefully selects beans 
from all over the world. Logistics teams manage 
bean delivery routes, and brave baristas across the city
serve this caffeinated elixir to scores of hurried customers. All in all, it takes hundreds of people
to get coffee to its intended destination— and that’s not counting everyone
maintaining the infrastructure that makes the journey possible. Many of these individuals work 
for low pay in dangerous conditions— and some aren’t paid at all. So while we might marvel at the global
network behind this commodity, let’s make sure we don’t value 
the final product more than the people who make it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the term for the small berries that contain the coffee seed?
Options: A. Coffee grapes, B. Coffee nuts, C. Coffee cherries, D. Coffee husks
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the primary function of the wet mill in the coffee production process? Options: A. To separate seeds from the fruit and sort them by density, B. To ferment coffee beans, C. To dry coffee seeds, D. To roast coffee beans Correct Option: A
Question 2: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of coffee production in Pitalito, Colombia. Options: A. Coffee cherries are picked, separated from the fruit, and then dried, B. Coffee beans are picked, fermented, and then dried, C. Coffee seeds are separated from the fruit, washed, and then dried, D. Coffee cherries are picked, separated from the fruit, fermented, and then dried Correct Option: D
Question 3: **Application**: If you were a coffee farmer in Pitalito, how would you ensure that your coffee seeds dry evenly? Options: A. By spreading them out on a large mesh rack and raking them regularly, B. By using a machine to dry them, C. By covering them with a tarp, D. By leaving them outside in the sun Correct Option: A
Question 4: **Analysis**: What are the main differences between the coffee production process in Pitalito and the process in a nearby mill? Options: A. The use of manual labor vs. machines, B. The type of coffee beans used, C. The location of the production process, D. The quality of the final product Correct Option: A
Question 5: **Synthesis**: How do the various stages of the coffee production process contribute to the final product? Options: A. Each stage adds a new ingredient, B. Each stage changes the flavor and aroma of the coffee, C. Each stage transforms the coffee from a raw material to a finished product, D. Each stage is unnecessary and can be skipped Correct Option: C
Question 6: **Evaluation**: What are the social implications of the coffee production process, particularly in Pitalito? Options: A. Low wages and poor working conditions for farmers and laborers, B. High wages and good working conditions, C. No social implications, D. The coffee production process is sustainable and environmentally friendly Correct Option: A

Question 8: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of roasting coffee beans. Options: A. The beans are heated in a machine to release oil, B. The beans are stirred by a metallic arm and heated by a gas-powered fire, C. The beans are sorted by size and color, D. The beans are ground and brewed Correct Option: B
Question 9: **Application**: If you would manage bean delivery routes? Options: A. By using a mapping app to optimize routes, B. By hiring a team of drivers to deliver the beans, C. By using a machine to sort and pack the beans, D. By leaving the beans at the warehouse Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation**: What are the environmental implications of the coffee production process, particularly in terms of transportation? Options: A. The use of fossil fuels contributes to climate change, B. The production process is sustainable and environmentally friendly, C. The transportation process is not significant enough to have an impact, D. The coffee production process does not have any environmental implications Correct Option: A
Question 11: **Knowledge**: What is the primary function of an optical scanner in the coffee production process? Options: A. To sort coffee beans by size and color, B. To evaluate the quality of the coffee, C. To dry coffee seeds, D. To separate seeds from the fruit Correct Option: A
Question 12: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of cupping coffee. Options: A. The coffee is roasted, ground, and then brewed, B. The coffee is evaluated for its taste, aroma, and mouthfeel, C. The coffee is sorted by size and color, D. The coffee is dried and then packaged Correct Option: B
Question 13: **Knowledge**: What is the role of a head buyer in the coffee production process? Options: A. To select beans from all over the world, B. To evaluate the quality of the coffee, C. To sort coffee beans by size and color, D. To select samples of beans to roast and brew Correct Option: A
Question 14: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of shipping coffee from tropical ports to the United States. Options: A. The coffee is transported by cargo ships crewed by over 25 people, B. The coffee is transported by airplanes, C. The coffee is transported by trucks, D. The coffee is transported by trains Correct Option: A
Question 15: **Application**: If you were a dockworker, how would you unload a container of coffee from a cargo ship? Options: A. By using a crane to lift the container off the ship, B. By using a forklift to move the container off the ship, C. By using a machine to sort and pack the coffee, D. By leaving the coffee on the ship Correct Option: A
Question 16: **Evaluation**: What are the social implications of the coffee production process, particularly in terms of labor practices? Options: A. Low wages and poor working conditions for farmers and laborers, B. High wages and good working conditions, C. No social implications, D. The coffee production process is sustainable and environmentally friendly Correct Option: A
Question 17: **Knowledge**: What is the primary function of a Q-grader in the coffee production process? Options: A. To evaluate the quality of the coffee, B. To select samples of beans to roast and brew, C. To sort coffee beans by size and color, D. To dry coffee seeds Correct Option: A
Question 18: **Comprehension**: Describe the process of roasting coffee beans. Options: A. The beans are heated in a machine to release oil, B. The beans are stirred by a metallic arm and heated by a gas-powered fire, C. The beans are sorted by size and color, D. The beans are ground and brewed Correct Option: B
Question 19: **Application**: If you would manage bean delivery routes? Options: A. By using a mapping app to optimize routes, B. By hiring a team of drivers to deliver the beans, C. By using a machine to sort and pack the coffee, D. By leaving the beans at the warehouse Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
How many people does it take to make
a cup of coffee? For many of us, all it takes is a short
walk and a quick pour. But this simple staple is the result 
of a globe-spanning process whose cost and complexity are far greater
than you might imagine. It begins in a place like the remote
Colombian town of Pitalito. Here, family farms have clear cut 
local forests to make room for neat rows of Coffea trees. These shrub-like plants 
were first domesticated in Ethiopia and are now cultivated throughout
equatorial regions. Each shrub is filled with small berries
called "coffee cherries." Since fruits on the same branch 
can ripen at different times, they’re best picked by hand, but each farm has its own method
for processing the fruit. In Pitalito, harvesters toil 
from dawn to dusk at high altitudes, often picking over 25 kilograms per shift
for very low wages. The workers deliver their picked cherries
to the wet mill. This machine separates the seeds
from the fruit, and then sorts them by density. The heaviest, most flavorful seeds 
sink to the bottom of the mill, where they’re collected 
and taken to ferment in a tub of water for one or two days. Then, workers wash off the remaining fruit
and put the seeds out to dry. Some farms use machines for this process, but in Pitalito, seeds are spread
onto large mesh racks. Over the next three weeks, 
workers rake the seeds regularly to ensure they dry evenly. Once the coffee beans are dry, a truck takes them to a nearby mill
with several specialized machines. An air blower re-sorts the seeds 
by density, an assortment of sieves filter 
them by size, and an optical scanner sorts by color. At this point, professionals called
Q-graders select samples of beans to roast and brew. In a process called "cupping," 
they evaluate the coffee’s taste, aroma, and mouthfeel to determine its quality. These experts give the beans a grade,
and get them ready to ship. Workers load burlap sacks 
containing up to 70 kilograms of dried and sorted coffee beans
onto steel shipping containers, each able to carry 
up to 21 metric tons of coffee. From tropical ports, cargo ships 
crewed by over 25 people transport coffee around the world But no country imports more coffee
than the United States, with New York City alone consuming
millions of cups every day. After the long journey 
from Colombia to New Jersey, our coffee beans pass through customs. Once dockworkers unload the container, a fleet of eighteen-wheelers transport 
the coffee to a nearby warehouse, and then to a roastery. Here the beans go into a roasting machine,
stirred by a metallic arm and heated by a gas-powered fire. Nearby sensors monitor the coffee’s
moisture level, chemical stability, and temperature, while trained coffee
engineers manually adjust these levels throughout the twelve-minute
roasting cycle. This process releases oil within the seed, transforming the seeds into grindable,
brewable beans with a dark brown color and rich aroma. After roasting, workers pack the beans
into five-pound bags, which a fleet of vans deliver to cafes
and stores across the city. The coffee is now so close 
you can smell it, but it needs more help 
for the final stretch. Each coffee company has a head buyer who carefully selects beans 
from all over the world. Logistics teams manage 
bean delivery routes, and brave baristas across the city
serve this caffeinated elixir to scores of hurried customers. All in all, it takes hundreds of people
to get coffee to its intended destination— and that’s not counting everyone
maintaining the infrastructure that makes the journey possible. Many of these individuals work 
for low pay in dangerous conditions— and some aren’t paid at all. So while we might marvel at the global
network behind this commodity, let’s make sure we don’t value 
the final product more than the people who make it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the title for professionals who select samples of beans to roast and brew?
Options: A. A-graders, B. C-graders, C. T-graders, D. Q-graders
Correct Option: D
